description: Enterprise techniques used by APT3, ATT&CK group G0022 v1.0
name: APT3 (G0022)

techniques.comment: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to use -WindowStyle Hidden to conceal [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1086) windows.

[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has interacted with compromised systems to browse and copy files through its graphical user interface in [Remote Desktop Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1076) sessions.
An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to add created accounts to local admin groups to maintain elevated access.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to use multiple backdoors per campaign.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to pack their tools.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to remove indicators of compromise from tools.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to brute force password hashes to be able to leverage plain text credentials.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to stage files for exfiltration in a single location.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) replaces the Sticky Keys binary C:\Windows\System32\sethc.exe for persistence.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) enables the Remote Desktop Protocol for persistence.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) will identify Microsoft Office documents on the victim's computer.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that looks for files and directories on the local file system.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can copy files to remote machines.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can detect the existence of remote systems.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) leverages valid accounts after gaining credentials for use within the victim domain.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can enumerate the permissions associated with Windows groups.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can list out currently running processes.

techniques.techniqueName: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
techniques.comment: [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that exfiltrates data over the C2 channel.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that creates a new service for persistence.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) obfuscates files or information to help evade defensive measures.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to create or enable accounts, such as support_388945a0.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can enumerate current network connections.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can run DLLs.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can obtain information about the local system.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used tools to compress data before exfilling it.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) uses commonly used ports (like HTTPS/443) for command and control.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) places scripts in the startup folder for persistence.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) will copy files over to Windows Admin Shares (like ADMIN$) as part of lateral movement.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can locate credentials in files on the file system such as those from Firefox or Chrome.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to side load DLLs with a valid version of Chrome with one of their tools.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can delete files.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used a tool that can obtain info about local and global group users, power users, and administrators.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used a keylogging tool that records keystrokes in encrypted files.
A keylogging tool used by [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) gathers network information from the victim, including the MAC address, IP address, WINS, DHCP server, and gateway.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used PowerShell on victim systems to download and run payloads after exploitation.

[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used a tool to dump credentials by injecting itself into lsass.exe and triggering with the argument "dig." The group has also used a tools to dump passwords from browsers.

An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader creates persistence by creating the following scheduled task: schtasks /create /tn "mysc" /tr C:\Users\Public\test.exe /sc ONLOGON /ru "System".
An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections to two separate IP addresses over TCP port 1913 and TCP port 81.
An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader uses the Windows command "cmd.exe" /C whoami. The group also uses a tool to execute commands on remote computers.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used PowerShell on victim systems to download and run payloads after exploitation.

An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader first establishes a SOCKS5 connection to 192.157.198[.]103 using TCP port 1913; once the server response is verified, it then requests a connection to 192.184.60[.]229 on TCP port 81.
An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.
An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader uses the Windows command "cmd.exe" /C whoami to verify that it is running with the elevated privileges of “System.”
